 There are a few fictional works which addressed this possibility and brought up interesting points. One is Aldous Huxley's book Brave New World. In it, people were grown in artificial wombs, not born, and they could be genetically designed. In the book, a high level official of this society mentions to the main character that an experiment had been tried in which all the people made were brilliant, athletic and beautiful - anyway, characteristics that we admire in people (nothing was said about picking their moral character). They ended up killing each other in competition for the better jobs and for leadership since nobody was willing to play the subservient menial role. Therefore, this society purposely grew humans who were at different levels (some very mentally deficient) to supply a distributions of people who could fit the distribution of roles necessary for society.
 
 Therefore, on an individual level, I don't have much of a problem with genetic engineering (assuming that we really fully knew what we are doing, which is doubtful since many unforseen side effects could occur). However, on a societal level, it could be very problematic.

 There are a few things I would be concerned about. 
 1) Would we really know what we are doing? From the limited amount I understand about genetics, things may not necessarily be as easy as "change that piece to change that characteristics". There is some level of interdependence in the way genes act in our bodies so I would be concerned that there might be unintended consequences to our haphazardly playing around with the human genome.
 2) Assuming we do know what we are doing, how do we decide what genetic improvements to make and who decides? What criteria do we use to make such decisions? Does society have a say? There are a lot of unsolved social issues that would need to be addressed. Even if we do address them, societies are complex and there may easily be unintended societal consequences to our well intended genetic manipulation of a future population. For example, if we made genetic changes which hugely prolongued people's average lifespan, then how does society care for such a large aged population?
 3) Even if we could solve all of these issues (which is a huge IF), should we "play God", so to speak. I don't have as much of an issue with this as others might. 
 4) The slippery slope: If, say, we agree as a society to make only those genetic changes that reduce birth defects and abnormalities, then what arguements do we present in law to limit genetic manipulation to only that? How do we argue against those who want to push things farther?
 5) If, in the womb, we change the genes of a fetus with a genetic disorder then, in many cases, we are changing what that fetus will become without its approval (assuming it already has a mental existence). I suppose you could limit genetic manipulation to pre-mental existence or wait until after the person is capable of agreeing to the procedure.
 
 Anyway, there are a host of problems that could arise. I am not saying that the problems may not be solveable. I am just wary of jumping into such a dangerous technology without thinking VERY HARD about what exactly it is that we are doing.

 I have mixed feelings about curing retardation. My hesitancy comes in the idea that we might be changing the very essence of a person without their permission (assuming that we are making the decision for them, since those with severe enough mental retardation would not be competent to make such a decision.). The positive is that one would think that removing that retardation for clearer thinking would be a good thing but, still, we don't know if it is their will.
 
 Even if genetic changes are made before any mental existence comes into play, there is the question of blame if the person thus changed does not like the alteration. Children blame their parents for enough things. With some degree of genetic engineering, they can justifiably blame them for their biological existence as well. Currently, you can't really blame your parents for your genes since your genes are not in their control. In the future, you will be able to. 
 
 Anyway, I have mixed feelings and haven't really decided either way about the morality of genetic engineering. For the time being, my strong concern is that we don't jump into it too quickly without spending a lot of effort looking into the possible reprecussions.

There are easier ways to go about a lot of what you suggested, I honestly have no qualms at all about genetic engineering as long as its done sensibly (I intend to make a career out of it afterall). However I think you need to look at the three main suggested uses of it -
 
 1.) Curing genetic diseases - seriously I can not see how you can argue against this sort of thing, even if its removing the traits from carriers. We're not at risk from becoming too homogenous and thus vunerable to disease,at this scale. The only potential issue is where there is some positive effect from the disease like the well known case of sickle cell anemia, but in a society where this technology is possible its really unlikely that there is going to be something like this that can't be treated otherwise. Worse comes to the worse, what is to stop you changing it back? Most of the diseases we're talking about occur during development and copying an existing genotype to adapt into gene therapy for an adult isn't really that difficult.
 
 2.) Give people a super immune system - this is really not that possible, partly due to the way the immune system works (most of the symptoms of every disease are caused by the immune system itself) and partly because bacteria and viruses evolve quicker than medicine. The technology could be used in medicine (we can do this now really, making non pathogenic strains or just the antigens for immunisation), but super-immune systems are out.
 
 3.) Make everyone a genius - again, there is no real need for this. Best way to think of this is like height, we are pretty much the tallest now as we've been throughout history as without an overabundance of food and a lack of parasites, you will not grow to your full height. Its not a simple 'tall gene' type thing, nor is intelligence. Mental diseases and retardation are things you could probably fix, these people aren't just at the bottom end of the normal distribution of intelligence but below that. They have a mental disease, they aren't stupid.
 What you really need is to concentrate on creating the environment where people can fully reach their potential, something that is far further beyond us at the moment than the genetic engineering is. Except in very special cases (that often border on the disease level), any inteligence boosting treatments would not really be noticeable unless accompanied by special programs designed to take advantage of it. If you want super intelligence, cybernetics is the way to go rather than gene therapy or genetic engineering.
